title: INTERSPEECH_2008_20_abs

sentences.text: In the study of expressive speech communication , it is commonly accepted that the emotion perceived by the listener is a good approximation of the intended emotion conveyed by the speaker .
This paper analyzes the validity of this assumption by comparing the mismatches between the assessments made by na ¨ ıve listeners and by the speakers that generated the data .
The analysis is based on the hypothesis that people are better decoders of their own emotions .
Therefore , self-assessments will be closer to the intended emotions .
Using the IEMOCAP database , discrete -LRB- categorical -RRB- and continuous -LRB- attribute -RRB- emotional assessments evaluated by the actors and na ¨ ıve listeners are compared .
The results indicate that there is a mismatch between the expression and perception of emotion .
The speakers in the database assigned their own emotions to more specific emotional categories , which led to more extreme values in the activation-valence space .

Entity-this_paper.label: This paper
Entity-this_paper.description: This paper investigates the discrepancies between the emotional assessments of naive listeners and the self-assessments of speakers in expressive speech communication, using the IEMOCAP database to analyze the accuracy of perceived versus intended emotions.

Entity-the_speaker_that_generated_the_da.label: the speakers that generated the data
aliases: the speakers that generated the data
Entity-the_speaker_that_generated_the_da.description: The speakers that generated the data refer to the individuals who produced the emotional speech samples used in the study, specifically the actors from the IEMOCAP database, whose self-assessments of their emotions are compared to the perceptions of na¨ıve listeners.

mentions.local_name: the speakers that generated the data

Entity-the_speaker_in_the_database.label: The speakers in the database
Entity-the_speaker_in_the_database.description: The speakers in the database refer to the actors from the IEMOCAP database who provided emotional assessments of their own performances in expressive speech communication.

Entity-mismatch_between_the_expression_a.label: mismatch between the expression and perception of emotion
aliases: mismatch between the expression and perception of emotion
Entity-mismatch_between_the_expression_a.description: The term 'mismatch between the expression and perception of emotion' refers to the discrepancy observed when the emotions that speakers intend to convey through their expressive speech do not align with the emotions perceived by listeners, highlighting differences in emotional assessment between self-evaluations by speakers and evaluations by naive listeners.

mentions.local_name: mismatch between the expression and perception of emotion

Entity-data.label: data
Entity-data.description: The term 'data' refers to the emotional assessments generated by speakers in the context of expressive speech communication, specifically those recorded in the IEMOCAP database.

Entity-mismatch.label: mismatches
Entity-mismatch.description: The term 'mismatches' refers to the discrepancies identified between the emotional assessments made by naive listeners and the self-assessments of the speakers in the context of expressive speech communication.

Entity-the_mismatch_between_the_assessme.label: the mismatches between the assessments
Entity-the_mismatch_between_the_assessme.description: The mismatches between the assessments refer to the discrepancies observed between the emotional evaluations made by naive listeners and the self-assessments provided by the speakers in expressive speech communication.

Entity-iemocap.label: IEMOCAP
Entity-iemocap.description: IEMOCAP is a multimodal database designed for the study of emotional expression in speech and includes recordings of actors performing scripted dialogues with emotional content.

Entity-speaker.label: speaker
Entity-speaker.description: The term 'speaker' refers to individuals who produce expressive speech and convey emotions, specifically those whose emotional expressions are analyzed in relation to listener perceptions in the context of the IEMOCAP database.

Entity-actor.label: actors
Entity-actor.description: The term 'actors' refers to the individuals who performed in the IEMOCAP database and provided emotional assessments of their own expressive speech.

Entity-assumption.label: assumption
Entity-assumption.description: The assumption refers to the widely accepted belief that the emotion perceived by a listener accurately reflects the intended emotion conveyed by a speaker in expressive speech communication.

Entity-the_emotion_perceived_by_the_list.label: the emotion perceived by the listener
aliases: the emotion perceived by the listener
Entity-the_emotion_perceived_by_the_list.description: The emotion perceived by the listener refers to the emotional response or interpretation that an audience member experiences when receiving expressive speech, which is often considered to reflect the speaker's intended emotional message.

mentions.local_name: the emotion perceived by the listener

Entity-the_validity_of_this_assumption.label: the validity of this assumption
Entity-the_validity_of_this_assumption.description: The validity of this assumption refers to the accuracy of the belief that the emotion perceived by listeners closely matches the intended emotion expressed by speakers in expressive speech communication.

Entity-emotional_assessment.label: emotional assessments
Entity-emotional_assessment.description: Emotional assessments refer to the evaluations of emotions, which can be discrete (categorical) or continuous (attribute-based), conducted by both actors and naive listeners to analyze the perception and expression of emotions in expressive speech communication.

Entity-discrete_-lrb-_categorical_-rrb-_.label: discrete -LRB- categorical -RRB- and continuous -LRB- attribute -RRB- emotional assessments
aliases: discrete -LRB- categorical -RRB- and continuous -LRB- attribute -RRB- emotional assessments
Entity-discrete_-lrb-_categorical_-rrb-_.description: Discrete (categorical) and continuous attribute emotional assessments refer to the methods of evaluating emotions where discrete assessments categorize emotions into specific groups, while continuous assessments measure emotions along a spectrum, both analyzed in the context of expressive speech communication.

mentions.local_name: discrete -LRB- categorical -RRB- and continuous -LRB- attribute -RRB- emotional assessments

Entity-the_intended_emotion.label: the intended emotions
Entity-the_intended_emotion.description: The intended emotions refer to the specific emotional states that a speaker aims to convey through their expressive speech, which are hypothesized to be more accurately assessed by the speaker themselves than by external listeners.

Entity-assessment.label: assessments
Entity-assessment.description: The term 'assessments' refers to the evaluations of emotional expressions made by both naive listeners and the speakers themselves, focusing on the discrepancies between their perceptions and intended emotions.

Entity-emotional_category.label: emotional categories
Entity-emotional_category.description: Emotional categories refer to the specific classifications of emotions that speakers assign to their own feelings, which are analyzed in the context of expressive speech communication to understand the discrepancies between self-assessment and listener perception.

Entity-the_study_of_expressive_speech_co.label: the study of expressive speech communication
aliases: the study of expressive speech communication
Entity-the_study_of_expressive_speech_co.description: The study of expressive speech communication refers to the research and analysis of how emotions are conveyed through speech and how they are perceived by listeners, focusing on the relationship between the speaker's intended emotions and the listener's interpretations.

mentions.local_name: the study of expressive speech communication

Entity-expressive_speech_communication.label: expressive speech communication
Entity-expressive_speech_communication.description: Expressive speech communication is a field of study that examines how emotions are conveyed through speech and how they are perceived by listeners, focusing on the relationship between the speaker's intended emotions and the listener's interpretations.

Entity-expression.label: expression
Entity-expression.description: The term 'expression' refers to the conveyance of emotions through speech, highlighting the discrepancies between how speakers intend to communicate their emotions and how those emotions are perceived by listeners.

Entity-na__ve_listener.label: na ¨ ıve listeners
Entity-na__ve_listener.description: Naïve listeners refer to individuals who assess emotional expressions in speech without prior knowledge or expertise in emotional decoding, serving as a comparison group to the self-assessments made by the speakers themselves.

Entity-the_intended_emotion_conveyed_by_.label: the intended emotion conveyed by the speaker
aliases: the intended emotion conveyed by the speaker
Entity-the_intended_emotion_conveyed_by_.description: The intended emotion conveyed by the speaker refers to the specific emotional state or feeling that the speaker aims to express through their speech, which may differ from how listeners perceive that emotion.

mentions.local_name: the intended emotion conveyed by the speaker

Entity-the_analysis.label: The analysis
Entity-the_analysis.description: The analysis refers to the examination of the hypothesis that individuals are more accurate in interpreting their own emotional expressions compared to those perceived by others, as explored through comparisons of self-assessments and assessments by naive listeners.

Entity-their_own_emotion.label: their own emotions
Entity-their_own_emotion.description: The term 'their own emotions' refers to the subjective emotional experiences and self-assessments of individuals regarding their feelings, which are hypothesized to be more accurately recognized and categorized by themselves compared to external observers.

Entity-the_hypothesis_that_people_are_be.label: the hypothesis that people are better decoders of their own emotions
aliases: the hypothesis that people are better decoders of their own emotions
Entity-the_hypothesis_that_people_are_be.description: The hypothesis that individuals possess a superior ability to accurately interpret and understand their own emotional states compared to external observers.

mentions.local_name: the hypothesis that people are better decoders of their own emotions

Entity-perception.label: perception
Entity-perception.description: In this context, 'perception' refers to the listener's interpretation and understanding of the emotional expressions conveyed by the speaker, highlighting the discrepancies between what is expressed and what is perceived.

Entity-analysis.label: analysis
Entity-analysis.description: The analysis refers to the examination of the hypothesis that individuals are more accurate in interpreting their own emotional expressions compared to those perceived by others.

Entity-activation-valence_space.label: activation-valence space
Entity-activation-valence_space.description: The activation-valence space is a psychological construct used to represent emotions in terms of their activation level and valence, which helps in understanding the relationship between expressed and perceived emotions in expressive speech communication.

Entity-the_result.label: The results
Entity-the_result.description: The results refer to the findings of the study, which reveal a discrepancy between how emotions are expressed by speakers and how they are perceived by listeners.

Entity-the_expression_and_perception_of_.label: the expression and perception of emotion
aliases: the expression and perception of emotion
Entity-the_expression_and_perception_of_.description: the expression and perception of emotion refers to the processes through which individuals convey and interpret emotional states, encompassing both the outward display of emotions and the internal recognition and understanding of those emotions in oneself and others.

mentions.local_name: the expression and perception of emotion

Entity-more_specific_emotional_category.label: more specific emotional categories
Entity-more_specific_emotional_category.description: More specific emotional categories refer to distinct classifications of emotions that allow speakers to convey their feelings with greater precision, resulting in more pronounced representations in the activation-valence emotional space.

Entity-more_extreme_value_in_the_activat.label: more extreme values in the activation-valence space
aliases: more extreme values in the activation-valence space
Entity-more_extreme_value_in_the_activat.description: The phrase 'more extreme values in the activation-valence space' refers to the heightened emotional intensity and specificity assigned by speakers to their own emotions, as measured within a framework that categorizes emotions based on their activation (energy level) and valence (pleasantness or unpleasantness).

mentions.local_name: more extreme values in the activation-valence space

Entity-people.label: people
Entity-people.description: In this context, 'people' refers to individuals who are capable of interpreting and understanding their own emotional states, specifically in relation to expressive speech communication.

Entity-listener.label: listener
Entity-listener.description: The 'listener' refers to an individual or participant who perceives and interprets the emotional content of speech, particularly in the context of expressive communication.

Entity-more_extreme_value.label: more extreme values
Entity-more_extreme_value.description: The term 'more extreme values' refers to the heightened emotional intensity represented in the activation-valence space, resulting from speakers categorizing their emotions into more specific and intense emotional categories.

Entity-self-assessments.label: self-assessments
Entity-self-assessments.description: Self-assessments are evaluation methods where individuals evaluate their own abilities, feelings, or performance, often used in psychological contexts to gain insight into personal experiences and emotions.

Entity-emotion.label: emotion
Entity-emotion.description: Emotion refers to a complex psychological state that involves a subjective experience, physiological response, and behavioral or expressive response, often categorized into various types such as happiness, sadness, anger, and fear.

Entity-database.label: database
Entity-database.description: A database is a structured collection of data that is stored and accessed electronically, typically managed by a database management system.

Entity-result.label: results
Entity-result.description: Results refer to the findings or outcomes derived from a study or analysis.

Entity-hypothesis.label: hypothesis
Entity-hypothesis.description: A hypothesis is a proposed explanation or theory that can be tested through research and experimentation.

Entity-paper.label: paper
Entity-paper.description: A paper is a written document that presents research findings, analyses, or arguments, typically in an academic or scholarly context.

summary: In the study of expressive speech communication , it is commonly accepted that the emotion perceived by the listener is a good approximation of the intended emotion conveyed by the speaker . This paper analyzes the validity of this assumption by comparing the mismatches between the assessments made by na ¨ ıve listeners and by the speakers that generated the data . The analysis is based on the hypothesis that people are better decoders of their own emotions . Therefore , self-assessments will be closer to the intended emotions . Using the IEMOCAP database , discrete -LRB- categorical -RRB- and continuous -LRB- attribute -RRB- emotional assessments evaluated by the actors and na ¨ ıve listeners are compared . The results indicate that there is a mismatch between the expression and perception of emotion . The speakers in the database assigned their own emotions to more specific emotional categories , which led to more extreme values in the activation-valence space .

Predicate-is_a_good_approximation_of.label: is a good approximation of
Predicate-is_a_good_approximation_of.description: The predicate 'is a good approximation of' indicates a relationship where the subject represents a close or reasonable representation of the object, suggesting that while there may be differences, the subject captures the essential qualities or characteristics of the object effectively enough to be considered similar or comparable.

Predicate-is_conveyed_by.label: is conveyed by
Predicate-is_conveyed_by.description: The predicate 'is conveyed by' establishes a relationship where the subject represents a concept, idea, or emotion that is expressed or communicated through the actions, words, or presence of the object. It indicates that the object plays a crucial role in transmitting or making the subject understood to others.

Predicate-analyzes.label: analyzes
Predicate-analyzes.description: The predicate 'analyzes' indicates an action performed by the subject that involves examining, interpreting, or evaluating the object in detail. It suggests a systematic approach to understanding the components, structure, or implications of the object, often with the aim of drawing conclusions or gaining insights.

Predicate-are_compared.label: are compared
Predicate-are_compared.description: The predicate 'are compared' indicates a relationship where the subject is evaluated or analyzed in relation to the object, highlighting similarities, differences, or other relevant characteristics between them. This comparison serves to draw insights or conclusions based on the attributes or qualities of both the subject and the object.

Predicate-is_based_on.label: is based on
Predicate-is_based_on.description: The predicate 'is based on' establishes a foundational relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject derives its principles, conclusions, or framework from the object. It suggests that the subject's validity, reasoning, or structure is contingent upon the object, which serves as a source of support or justification.

Predicate-involves.label: involves
Predicate-involves.description: The predicate 'involves' indicates a relationship where the subject encompasses or requires the presence or participation of the object. It suggests that the object is a necessary component or aspect of the subject, highlighting a connection where the subject cannot be fully understood or realized without the object.

Predicate-are_better_decoders_of.label: are better decoders of
Predicate-are_better_decoders_of.description: The predicate 'are better decoders of' indicates a comparative ability or skill of the subject in interpreting, understanding, or analyzing the object. It suggests that the subject possesses a higher proficiency or effectiveness in deciphering the nuances, meanings, or signals associated with the object, which often pertains to complex or abstract concepts.

Predicate-will_be_closer_to.label: will be closer to
Predicate-will_be_closer_to.description: The predicate 'will be closer to' indicates a future state of proximity or alignment between the subject and the object. It suggests that the subject is expected to achieve a greater degree of similarity, accuracy, or relevance in relation to the object over time. This implies a process of improvement or adjustment that leads to a more harmonious or accurate connection between the two entities.

Predicate-compares.label: compares
Predicate-compares.description: The predicate 'compares' indicates a relationship in which the subject evaluates or analyzes the similarities and/or differences between itself and the object. This involves assessing various attributes, characteristics, or qualities to establish a relationship of equivalence, contrast, or distinction.

Predicate-evaluated_by.label: evaluated by
Predicate-evaluated_by.description: The predicate 'evaluated by' indicates a relationship where the subject is subjected to an assessment or judgment performed by the object. It signifies that the object, typically a person or group, is responsible for analyzing, interpreting, or providing feedback on the subject, thereby establishing a dynamic of evaluation and appraisal.

Predicate-evaluates.label: evaluates
Predicate-evaluates.description: The predicate 'evaluates' signifies an action where the subject performs an assessment or analysis of the object, determining its quality, value, or significance. In this context, the subject applies criteria or standards to the object to derive conclusions or insights about it.

Predicate-indicate.label: indicate
Predicate-indicate.description: The predicate 'indicate' serves to establish a relationship where the subject provides evidence, signs, or suggestions that point towards or reveal the existence or nature of the object. It implies that the subject conveys information that leads to an understanding or awareness of the object, often suggesting a conclusion or inference that can be drawn from the subject's characteristics or findings.

Predicate-is_between.label: is between
Predicate-is_between.description: The predicate 'is between' indicates a relational position or state where the subject exists in a middle or intermediary role concerning the object. It suggests that the subject serves as a link or connection that separates or relates two distinct entities or concepts represented by the object. This relationship often implies a dynamic interaction or contrast between the two entities, highlighting the subject's role in the context of their relationship.

Predicate-assigned.label: assigned
Predicate-assigned.description: The predicate 'assigned' indicates a relationship in which the subject designates or allocates a specific role, task, or attribute to the object. In this context, it implies that the subject has the authority or capability to determine the nature of the object, which can represent a concept, feeling, or responsibility. The action of assigning suggests a transfer of responsibility or a formal recognition of a particular state or condition associated with the object.

Predicate-to.label: to
Predicate-to.description: The predicate 'to' serves as a connector that indicates a directional relationship from the subject to the object, often implying a transformation, specification, or elaboration of the subject. In the context of the example triple, it suggests that the subject (emotion) is being refined or categorized into more specific emotional categories, thereby establishing a link that enhances understanding or classification.

Predicate-led_to.label: led to
Predicate-led_to.description: The predicate 'led to' indicates a causal or consequential relationship between the subject and the object, where the subject is understood to be a contributing factor or condition that results in the occurrence or existence of the object. It implies that the subject has a direct influence or effect on the object, suggesting a progression or transformation from one state to another.

Predicate-analyzes_the_discrepancies_bet.label: analyzes the discrepancies between the emotional assessments of naive listeners and the self-assessments of the speakers that generated the data
Predicate-analyzes_the_discrepancies_bet.description: The predicate describes an analytical process that involves comparing and contrasting two sets of emotional evaluations: one set derived from naive listeners and the other from the self-assessments made by the speakers who produced the data. It highlights the examination of differences or inconsistencies between these assessments, thereby facilitating a deeper understanding of how emotions are perceived by external observers versus how they are internally recognized by the speakers themselves.

Predicate-analyzes_the_emotional_assessm.label: analyzes the emotional assessments of
Predicate-analyzes_the_emotional_assessm.description: The predicate 'analyzes the emotional assessments of' indicates a relationship where the subject conducts a detailed examination or evaluation of the emotional evaluations or judgments made regarding the object. This implies that the subject seeks to understand, interpret, or derive insights from the emotional assessments associated with the object, which typically involves a systematic approach to understanding feelings, sentiments, or emotional responses.

Predicate-are_the_same_as.label: are the same as
Predicate-are_the_same_as.description: The predicate 'are the same as' establishes an equivalence relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that they refer to identical entities or concepts. It implies that there is no distinction between the two in the context being discussed, suggesting that they share all relevant characteristics or attributes.

Predicate-assess.label: assess
Predicate-assess.description: The predicate 'assess' indicates an evaluative action performed by the subject on the object, where the subject examines, analyzes, or judges the characteristics, quality, or significance of the object in order to form a conclusion or understanding about it.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a more specific instance or category that falls under the wider category represented by the object. This relationship suggests that the object encompasses a larger scope or a more general concept that includes the subject within its definition.
